ticket.title: ActiveRecord.clone does not clear out timestamps
ticket.original-body:
The docs says that a cloned object is 'treated as a new record', however the updated_at/created_at timestamps seems to be persisted after the save! This is a bit counter intuitive.
I'm using the following monkey patch to work around this:
module ActiveRecord class Base def clone_with_no_timestamps record = clone_without_no_timestamps record.updated_at = nil if record.respond_to?(:updated_at) record.created_at = nil if record.respond_to?(:created_at) record end
alias_method_chain :clone, :no_timestamps end end
ticket.latest-body:
The docs says that a cloned object is 'treated as a new record', however the updated_at/created_at timestamps seems to be persisted after the save! This is a bit counter intuitive.
I'm using the following monkey patch to work around this:
module ActiveRecord class Base def clone_with_no_timestamps record = clone_without_no_timestamps record.updated_at = nil if record.respond_to?(:updated_at) record.created_at = nil if record.respond_to?(:created_at) record end
alias_method_chain :clone, :no_timestamps end end
ticket.original-body-html:
The docs says that a cloned object is 'treated as a new record', however the updated_at/created_at timestamps seems to be persisted after the save! This is a bit counter intuitive.

I'm using the following monkey patch to work around this:

module ActiveRecord

class Base
  def clone_with_no_timestamps
    record = clone_without_no_timestamps
    record.updated_at = nil if record.respond_to?(:updated_at)
    record.created_at = nil if record.respond_to?(:created_at)
    record
  end

  alias_method_chain :clone, :no_timestamps
end

end

version.body:
The docs says that a cloned object is 'treated as a new record', however the updated_at/created_at timestamps seems to be persisted after the save! This is a bit counter intuitive.
I'm using the following monkey patch to work around this:
module ActiveRecord class Base def clone_with_no_timestamps record = clone_without_no_timestamps record.updated_at = nil if record.respond_to?(:updated_at) record.created_at = nil if record.respond_to?(:created_at) record end
alias_method_chain :clone, :no_timestamps end end
version.body-html:
The docs says that a cloned object is 'treated as a new record', however the updated_at/created_at timestamps seems to be persisted after the save! This is a bit counter intuitive.

I'm using the following monkey patch to work around this:

module ActiveRecord

class Base
  def clone_with_no_timestamps
    record = clone_without_no_timestamps
    record.updated_at = nil if record.respond_to?(:updated_at)
    record.created_at = nil if record.respond_to?(:created_at)
    record
  end

  alias_method_chain :clone, :no_timestamps
end

end
version.title: ActiveRecord.clone does not clear out timestamps

version.body: Here's a patch against master. It's forcing **updated_at**, **updated_on**, **created_at** and **created_on** to **nil** on the clone object.
version.body-html: Here's a patch against master. It's forcing updated_at, updated_on, created_at and created_on to nil on the clone object.
version.title: ActiveRecord.clone does not clear out timestamps

version.body:
+1
This patch applies cleanly. It's well tested. All tests passed.
version.body-html:
+1

This patch applies cleanly. It's well tested. All tests passed.
version.title: ActiveRecord.clone does not clear out timestamps

version.body: If clone method is going to wipe out timestamps then clone should accpet an option (:preserve_timestamps => true) that will preserve timestamps incase I need it.
version.body-html: If clone method is going to wipe out timestamps then clone should accpet an option (:preserve_timestamps => true) that will preserve timestamps incase I need it.
version.title: ActiveRecord.clone does not clear out timestamps

version.body:
-1
There is a problem with current patch with models that have no created_at/updated_at fields. For that kind of models following test will fail:
@@@ ruby test "cloned model attributes" do token = Token.new # model without created_at/updated_at timestamps cloned_token = token.clone
[:created_at, :updated_at].each do |key| assert_equal token.has_attribute?(key), cloned_token.has_attribute?(key) end end @@@
version.body-html:
-1

There is a problem with current patch with models that have no created_at/updated_at fields.
For that kind of models following test will fail:

test "cloned model attributes" do
  token = Token.new # model without created_at/updated_at timestamps
  cloned_token = token.clone

  [:created_at, :updated_at].each do |key|
    assert_equal token.has_attribute?(key), cloned_token.has_attribute?(key)
  end
end
version.title: ActiveRecord.clone does not clear out timestamps

version.body:
Here's a more complete patch, that takes into account the comment made by pleax.
Neeraj, from what I've learned so far, AR::Base does not override @clone@ (or @dup@). It just overrides its specific behavior by defining @initialize_copy@.
So if one need to preserve the timestamps, this would need to be redefined by another specific @initialize_copy@ method in one's own classes.
Is this an acceptable solution? If not, I'll have to reintroduce @clone@ and I'm almost sure it's a bad idea if I refer to ticket/patch #3164.
Thanks for your feedbacks!
version.body-html:
Here's a more complete patch, that takes into account the comment made by pleax.

Neeraj, from what I've learned so far, AR::Base does not override clone (or dup). It just overrides its specific behavior by defining initialize_copy.

So if one need to preserve the timestamps, this would need to be redefined by another specific initialize_copy method in one's own classes.

Is this an acceptable solution? If not, I'll have to reintroduce clone and I'm almost sure it's a bad idea if I refer to ticket/patch #3164.

Thanks for your feedbacks!
version.title: ActiveRecord.clone does not clear out timestamps

version.title: ActiveRecord.clone does not clear out timestamps

version.body: I don't agree with doing that way i prefer the default behavior the way it is and an option (:preserve_timestamps => false)
version.body-html: I don't agree with doing that way i prefer the default behavior the way it is and an option (:preserve_timestamps => false)
version.title: ActiveRecord.clone does not clear out timestamps

version.body: Perhaps `dup` should keep the timestamps (identical copy) and `clone` should not (new copy).
version.body-html: Perhaps dup should keep the timestamps (identical copy) and clone should not (new copy).
version.title: ActiveRecord.clone does not clear out timestamps

version.body: Jeremy: @dup@ is already preserving the timestamps (it's not using @initialize_copy@).
version.body-html: Jeremy: dup is already preserving the timestamps (it's not using initialize_copy).
version.title: ActiveRecord.clone does not clear out timestamps

version.body:
+1
All ar-mysql- and -postgresql-tests pass (well, there are 2 failures for postgresql and 2 failures and 1 error for mysql, but they are the same without the path), patch applies cleanly, behaviour makes sense
version.body-html:
+1

version.title: ActiveRecord.clone does not clear out timestamps

version.body: What happened to this ticket? I would love for this to change. I think the preserve_timestamps timestamps option is good, but I think it makes more sense for the timestamps not to be preserved by default.
version.body-html: What happened to this ticket? I would love for this to change. I think the preserve_timestamps timestamps option is good, but I think it makes more sense for the timestamps not to be preserved by default.
version.title: ActiveRecord.clone does not clear out timestamps

version.body: I've applied Cesario's patches to master. `dup` will not preserve timestamps.
version.body-html: I've applied Cesario's patches to master. dup will not preserve timestamps.
